sub_topic: Time dilation in a moving frame of reference
message_1: A spaceship travels with a speed of 0.8c relative to the earth. An astronaut on board measures the time elapsed between two events in his frame of reference to be 10 seconds. What is the time elapsed between the same two events as measured by an observer on earth? Use the formula for time dilation in special relativity to solve the problem.
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the time dilation formula in special relativity, which is given by:

Δt = Δt0 / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)

where Δt is the time elapsed as measured by an observer on Earth (the dilated time), Δt0 is the proper time elapsed as measured by the astronaut on board the spaceship (10 seconds in this case), v is the relative velocity of the spaceship (0.8c), and c is the speed of light.

Plugging in the given values, we get:

Δt = 10 / sqrt(1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2)

Δt = 10 / sqrt(1 - 0.64)

Δt = 10 / sqrt(0.36)

Δt = 10 / 0.6

Δt ≈ 16.67 seconds

So, the time elapsed between the same two events as measured by an observer on Earth is approximately 16.67 seconds.
